fitChecklist.title: 10 practical questions to check fit
fitChecklist.description: Grounded prompts so you can verify whether this coaching space is the right match without leaving the page.

items.question: Q1｜If coaching weren’t an option, what would you do?
items.answer: You could Google, watch videos, or ask friends. Coaching matters when you already want change but feel stuck in real-world constraints like language, status, family, culture, or age.

items.question: Q2｜Why me, not any generic coach?
items.answer: I live the UK restart reality and don’t sell hype. I use structured thinking—breaking down money, time, status, family duties, and skills—so you can see your options clearly.

items.question: Q3｜How am I different from other UK-based Chinese/Taiwanese coaches?
items.answer: I focus on mid-career, returners, and complex family/visa contexts. I bring cross-cultural, family, and startup layers, and I’m careful not to overpromise—ideal for people allergic to success-theatre.

items.question: Q4｜What visible outcomes appear after 3 months?
items.answer: (1) A decision map with money/time/risks/emotional costs. (2) Executable rhythms and boundary scripts. (3) Written self-definitions you can revisit—not just “more confidence.”

items.question: Q5｜Why is pricing defensible?
items.answer: You are buying 3–6 months of critical-transition support, not hours. A mis-aimed career or migration decision is far costlier than the fee; steady decision quality is the value.

items.question: Q6｜Who will feel safe with my style, who may not?
items.answer: Style: calm, deep, structured, and honest about limits—no hype. If you want to be pumped up fast, this isn’t it. If you want frank conversations and steady pacing, you’ll feel held.

items.question: Q7｜What proof points can be verified?
items.answer: Work across Taiwan and the UK, family and migration experience, entrepreneurship, plus downloadable tools (boundaries practice, time logs, emotion maps) and named frameworks.

items.question: Q8｜If I only share three USPs, what are they?
items.answer: Cross-cultural, mid-career, family-responsibility realism; no dream-selling—acknowledge limits but keep moving; structured thinking with concrete tools, not just chat.

items.question: Q9｜If another coach looks similar, how do I shore up trust?
items.answer: Build trust with content and transparency: show session cadence, assignments, and tools; say clearly what coaching won’t cover and offer referrals when therapy or other help is safer.

items.question: Q10｜Most candid reminder and next step?
items.answer: No one pays because I try hard; they pay when I’m the best person to help them decide and endure right now. Write out the three typical clients, their pains, fears, and 3/6-month shifts, then weave that into the site, service pages, and first-call opener.

icfNotice.paragraph1: We coach in line with the International Coaching Federation Code of Ethics. Coaching is a collaborative, client-led partnership that supports your self-directed learning and change. It is not therapy, counselling, medical, legal or financial advice. You remain responsible for your choices and actions.
icfNotice.paragraph2: We maintain confidentiality except where required by law or where there is a risk of harm. Together we set clear agreements, goals, and boundaries before we begin, and we obtain your informed consent for how we work and how your information is handled.
